Activities of daily living assessment in spinal cord injury using the virtual reality system Toyra®: functional and kinematic correlations
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 25 September 2015

Activities of daily living assessment in spinal cord injury using the virtual reality system Toyra®: functional and kinematic correlations

  • I. Dimbwadyo-Terrer1,2,
  • F. Trincado-Alonso1,
  • A. De los Reyes-Guzmán1,
  • P. López-Monteagudo3,
  • B. Polonio-López4 &
  • A. Gil-Agudo1 

Virtual Reality volume 20, pages17–26(2016)Cite this article

  • 613 Accesses

  • 3 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The main objective of this study was to analyze the correlations between functional scales and kinematic data collected during the execution of upper limb (UL) basic activities of daily living in an immersive virtual reality (VR) environment. Fifteen people with tetraplegia participated in the study. Moreover, we also want to confirm if changes in UL functional performance detected by functional scales are also detected by the VR system Toyra®. Patients were assessed before and after 4 weeks of daily conventional rehabilitation treatment complemented with a training with the VR system. Significant positive correlations between kinematic and functional parameters were found in the post assessment, verifying that changes in UL functional performance detected by functional scales are also measured by the VR system Toyra®, concretely the related to shoulder movements. Additionally, a predefined Agility metric has been applied, showing inversely proportional results to the level of injury, as we expected. The self-care category of the Spinal Cord Independence Measure (SCIM III) and the ranges of motion (ROM) captured with the VR system were analyzed, showing statistical significance changes between pre-post evaluations, supporting the hypothesis that kinematic analysis complements clinical and functional assessments of patients with tetraplegia.

Introduction

Impairment of UL is one of the most common sequelae following neurological injuries (Alt Murphy et al. 2006). In spinal cord injury (SCI), specifically in tetraplegia, the arm and hand function is affected to varying degrees, depending on the level and severity of the injury (Harvey et al. 2001). UL have an important role in several ADL such as eating, drinking, clothing, grooming or writing, as well as in different sports and leisure activities, requiring the coordination of several joints and involving both musculoskeletal and neural systems (Alt Murphy et al. 2006). It means that impairments in the UL function can have a profound impact on the independence and quality of life of the affected individuals, influencing muscle strength, movement and coordination, inter alia.

Despite there are many tests available designed to evaluate UL function, only few seem suitable for use in people with tetraplegia (van Tuijl et al. 2002). One of the most used functional measure for patients with tetraplegia is the Spinal Cord Independence Measure (SCIM) (Catz et al. 1997), a disability scale developed specifically for SCI persons in order to make the functional assessments of people with paraplegia or tetraplegia more sensitive to changes (van Tuijl et al. 2002). However, currently available functional and clinical scales are not sensible enough to assess motor strategies used during movements (Cacho et al. 2011). More objective and accurate analysis are needed to describe UL motor function more precisely and, specifically, during functional tasks (Alt Murphy et al. 2006).

Kinematic analysis can produce detailed data about motor strategies associated with daily living tasks (Cacho et al. 2011), which are of particular relevance to clinical practice since they provide essential information of a person’s real capabilities (Alt Murphy et al. 2006). In particular, three-dimensional motion capture systems have turned out to be a powerful tool for quantitative assessment of UL movements (De Los Reyes-Guzmán et al. 2013). When used in combination with Virtual Reality (VR), kinematic analysis allows to develop a human performance testing and training environment (Lee et al. 2003). VR is defined as a simulation of a real environment generated by computer in which, through a man–machine interface, it allows the user to interact with certain elements inside a simulated scenario (Weiss et al. 2006). Using VR technology, we can replicate daily environments, allowing to evaluate skills of practical relevance (Dimbwadyo-Terrer et al. 2013; Trincado-Alonso et al. 2014; Cameirao et al. 2011), and providing a level of realism unattainable by other techniques Lee et al. (2003). Complete control over content is possible, and performance data may be stored in real time in a database. Moreover, VR provides motivation to rehabilitation programs, by adding gaming factors in safe and controlled virtual environments, eliminating risks and adapting exercises to patients’ demands (Lee et al. 2003).

Within this context, several studies (Cacho et al. 2011; Dimbwadyo-Terrer et al. 2013) emphasize the importance of correlating kinematic variables with clinical and functional measures. This information could help to design standardized tests to precisely assess UL motor function, which in turn would help clinicians in the knowledge of patients’ physical state and clinical evolution (Trincado-Alonso et al. 2014; Zariffa et al. 2012).

Thus the objectives of the present study were (1) to analyze the correlations between functional scales and kinematic data collected during the execution of UL functional tasks in a VR environment, (2) to define if a functional metric obtain from the VR system was suitable for clinical assessment, and (3) to verify whether changes in UL functional performance detected by functional scales are also measured by the VR system.

Methods

Participants

Fifteen subjects with motor complete cervical SCI (6 females and 9 males; aged \(34.53 \pm 13.71\) years, \(4.33 \pm 2.13\) months after injury) participated in the study. The subjects’ demographic and clinical characteristics are showed in the Table 1. All the subjects had to fulfill the following inclusion criteria: (1) at least 18 years of age; (2) less than 12 months from the injury; (3) complete spinal cord injury according to ASIA impairment scale at the level of C5 to C8 (A-B ASIA level); and (4) normal or corrected-to-normal vision and hearing. We excluded from the study people with history of traumatic or cognitive pathology that can affect the upper limb movements, technology addiction and/or epilepsy and pregnancy. Each subject gave informed consent voluntarily which was approved by the local Ethics Committee.

Assessment

For the kinematic capture process, a motion capture system based on inertial sensors MTx Xsens Company (Xsens Ic, Netherlands) was used which comprised a set of five sensors.

Each inertial sensor included a gyroscope, an accelerometer and a magnetometer each sensor, which allowed us to know the position in Cartesian space.

For this application, the inertial sensors were located on the head, trunk, arm, forearm and hand (see Fig. 1). The captured inertial sensor and UL anthropometric data were used to develop a biomechanical model that has been previously described by Gil-Agudo et al. (2011). The training system used was the VR Toyra®, which reproduces, in real time, the movements of the patient through an avatar displayed on an LCD screen (Gil-Agudo et al. 2012). A series of objects are shown, and the avatar, which represents the patient in mirror view, has to touch them, while following trajectories that represent functional movements. The system asks patients to take the virtual objects (i.e., fork, spoon, comb) and execute the activity related to them (i.e., bring it to your mouth, comb your hair...). The kinematic assessment protocol consisted in the recording of UL ROM, while performing 5 exercises of a basic ADL session of Toyra® system. For the data analysis we take into account the first (pre) and the last (post) session of the module.

Additionally, an Agility metric (see Eq. 1) based on the kinematic data obtained during the Toyra® sessions has been applied in this work. This metric has been previously defined by Trincado-Alonso et al. (2014). The definition of this metric takes into consideration that an agile movement should be not only fast, but also precise.

$$\begin{aligned} \hbox {Ag}=100-\frac{20\cdot \frac{d_{\mathrm{mean}}}{d_{\max }}+30\cdot \frac{v_{\max }}{v_{\mathrm{mean}}}+50\frac{t}{t_{\mathrm{ideal}}}}{100} \end{aligned}$$
(1)

where:

\(d_{\mathrm{mean}}\) (m):

Mean distance from the trajectory performed by the patient’s hand to the ideal trajectory of the hand performed by a healthy subject

\(d_{\max }\) (m):

Maximum distance between the trajectory performed by the patient’s hand and the ideal trajectory of the hand performed by a healthy subject

\(v_{\max }\)(\(^{\circ }\)/s):

Maximum angular velocity of the joint under study in each exercise

\(v_{\mathrm{mean}}\)(\(^{\circ }\)/s):

Mean angular velocity of the joint under study in each exercise

t(s):

Time spent by the patient on performing the exercise i

\(t_{\mathrm{ideal}}\) (s):

Time spent by a healthy subject on performing the exercise i

Precision is considered by the relationship between \(d_{\mathrm{mean}}\) and \(d_{\max }\). The idea of this equation is to penalize the accuracy of those trajectories that present several peaks of deviation in respect to the ideal trajectory. If they have a few peaks, \(d_{\mathrm{mean}}\) will not be affected to a great extent by these peaks, so that \(d_{\mathrm{mean}} \ll d_{\max }\), and thus the penalization for the accuracy would be approximately 2 \(d_{\mathrm{mean}}\). However, if there are a lot of peaks of deviation, \(d_{\mathrm{mean}}\) will be affected by these values, so that \(d_{\mathrm{mean}}\) will increase. Consider as an example an extreme case in which there were so many peaks of deviation that \(d_{\mathrm{mean}}\approx d_{\max }\); then the penalization for the accuracy would be 4 \(d_{\mathrm{mean}}\), much higher than in the previous case. A very high maximum angular velocity is considered as a penalization, unless the mean velocity is also high. The reason to calculate it in this way is that patients with a badly preserved functionality will carry out the exercises quite slowly, obtaining a low mean angular velocity, but they also will carry out uncontrolled movements, for example dropping the arm, thus getting a high maximum angular velocity. Therefore, it is important to evaluate the relationship between the maximum and the mean angular velocity, not only one of them separately.

In order to obtain values in percentages, as in previous metrics, agility has been normalized by the average value of accuracy obtained by 6 healthy subjects (see Eq. 2):

$$\begin{aligned} \hbox {Ag}_{\mathrm{norm}}=\frac{\hbox {Ag}}{\hbox {Ag}_{\mathrm{ideal}}}\cdot 100\, [\%] \end{aligned}$$
(2)

The functional examination was carried out using SCIM III scale, which has been designed specifically for patients with SCI and is the only comprehensive ability rating scale for this patient population. SCIM III focuses on the ability of performing basic everyday tasks and takes into consideration the economic burden of disability as well as the impact of disability on the patient’s overall medical condition and comfort (Catz et al. 1997). SCIM III continues to gain widespread international acceptance and has been revised twice since the original version (the most recent version is the SCIM III) (Itzkovich et al. 2007). This scale has 16 items divided into three functional areas: self-care, respiration and sphincter management, and mobility. Total score can vary from 0 (minimal) to 100 (maximal). Only the self-care sub-score has been considered in this study, because it has been previously shown by Rudhe and van Hedel (2009) that the self-care category of the SCIM III and several of its items correlate well with upper extremity strength and capacity tests in persons with tetraplegia. SCIM III self-care sub-score has a total score of 20 points, where sub-items feeding, bathing and grooming score from 0 to 3, and sub-item dressing from 0 to 4.

Experimental design

The VR systems used was Toyra® system (www.toyra.org/en/) that provides to users a mirror image view of themselves actively participating within the environment (see Fig. 2). The use of the user’s own image was decided based on the kind of VR activities (many task in Toyra® require proximal movements), and on the idea that mirror view adds realism and sense of presence to the practice (Weiss et al. 2004). It also provides feedback about a client’s body posture and quality of movement, comparable to the use of video feedback in conventional rehabilitation. Two of the most important advantages of VR rehabilitation are interactivity and patient motivation Burdea (2003). Toyra® system provides visual and auditory rewards, displaying gratifying messages in real time (Great, Very Good, etc.), increasing patients’ motivation to exercise.

In this session the monitor displayed several daily living objects (spoon, fork, comb and/or sponge), and the patient has to perform different daily living task interacting with the virtual objects. This session comprises 10 exercises: reaching distal objects, doing proximal movements (touching your face, head and ear), eating with spoon, eating with a fork, drinking for a glass, cleaning your mouth, washing your face with a sponge, rubbing hands, rubbing your opposite shoulder and combing your hair.

The quantification of the range of UL joint motion required during the performance of a specific type of functional activity has been previously study, showing that shoulder internal rotation, shoulder flexion, forearm pronation, wrist flexion, and shoulder abduction, respectively, are some of the movements with highest importance and priority among elementary motions (Safaee-Rad et al. 1990). Following these advices, and taking into account the system measure characteristics, a total of 5 movements were investigated for this study: Shoulder flexion/extension (F/E), Shoulder abduction/adduction (ABD/ADD), Shoulder external/internal (I/E) rotation, Elbow pronation/supination (P/S) and Wrist F/E.

To characterize the movement, the ROM in degrees of every joint in each exercise was computed. The ROM is defined here as the difference between the maximum and minimum angles recorded for a given joint over the course of the VR task.

Of the 10 Toyra®’s exercises, we selected 5 of them: eating with spoon (spoon), eating with a fork (eatfork), drinking for a glass (drink), washing your face with a sponge (sponge) and combing your hair (comb), because they were the most similar to self-care category to SCIM III items and some of them were previously studied as daily activities in which UL has an important role (Safaee-Rad et al. 1990; De los Reyes-Guzmán et al. 2010).

For correlations we took in account the first and last session of Toyra systems and the results of the functional evaluation before and after the training.

All patients received a daily session of conventional Occupational Therapy and Physiotherapy, as part of their rehabilitation program, approximately 2 hours a day/every day. For this study we took into account the 4 weeks after a month from the beginning of the rehabilitation program, when patients are in the sub-acute phase (so it is expected improvements) but clinically stables. Simultaneously, they took part in a AVD training program that included 12 sessions with Toyra® during 30 min/day, 3 days a week during 4 weeks (see Fig. 3).

Every subject was evaluated twice: at the beginning of the study and at the end, using both the VR system and the SCIM III scale. The person who perform the clinical assessment was blinded to the VR training and the data analysis.

Data Analysis

The Spearman correlation coefficient was used to correlate kinematic variables (shoulder, elbow and wrist ROM) with functional variables (self-care category of the SCIM III). The total of the self-care category of the SCIM III and each item separately were correlated with the kinematics obtained by Toyra® exercises from the dominant arm (the arm used to perform the basic daily living tasks). A significance level of p less than 0.05 was used. The correlation coefficient was interpreted according to Hazard-Munro (2014): 0.00–0.25: small or no correlation; 0.26–0.49: low correlation; 0.50–0.69: moderate correlation; 0.70–0.89: high correlation; 0.90–1.00: very high correlation. To compare the mean values of the kinematics and functional parameters between pre- and post-session, the nonparametric Wilcoxon test was used. The statistical analysis was done with the program SPSS 17.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, EE.UU).

Results

Functional assessment

When comparing functional data, there was a statistically significant difference in the total score of SCIM III self-care category, and in 2 of the 6 self-care category variables of the SCIM III (Bathing upper body and Grooming) when comparing pre- and post-assessments. Related to kinematic data, obtained from Toyra®, we found a statistically significant difference between pre- and post-evaluation in 4 of the 5 tasks. Specifically, it was difference in 1 of the 3 joints analyzed (Shoulder F/E and ABD/ADD) in the exercise eatfork, 3 of the 3 (Shoulder F/E and ABD/ADD, Elbow P/S and Wrist F/E) in the drink exercise, 1 of the 3 (Wrist F/E) in the sponge exercise, and 2 of the 3 (Shoulder F/E, ABD/ADD and I/E rotation, and Wrist F/E) in the spoon exercise (2). There was no statistically significant difference in the comb exercise, but all items have showed positive clinical trends (Table 2).

Correlations between functional and kinematic parameters

Comparing correlations in the basal assessment (see Table 3), low negative correlations were found between 4 sub-items of SCIM III and kinematic parameters: the item 1 (Feeding) with Spoon Wrist F/E (r: −0.541*, p: 0.046); and Comb Shoulder ABD/ADD (r: −0.580*, p: 0.048); the item 4 (Dressing upper body) with Eatfork Elbow P/S (r: −0.593*; p: 0.025); the item 6 (Grooming) with Eatfork Wrist F/E (r: −0.658*, p: 0.010); and Drink Elbow P/S (r: −0.617*, p: 0.019). The total score of SCIM III self-care also showed low negative correlations with Eatfork Elbow P/S (r: −0.597*, p: 0.024); and Eatfork Wrist F/E (r: −0.583*, p: 0.029); and Drink Elbow P/S (r: −0.558*, p: 0.038).

For the post assessment, positive correlations between functional and kinematic variables were found (see Table 4) between the item 6 of SCIM III (Grooming) post and Spoon Shoulder F/E (\(r=0.621, p=0.018\)) and Spoon Shoulder ABD/ADD (\(r=0.689\), \(p=0.006\)). A low negative correlation was found between the item 2 (Bathing upper body) post and Drink Shoulder ABD/ADD post (\(r=-0.536, p=0.048\)).

The rest of SCIM and kinematic parameters did not showed any correlations.

Kinematic metric of agility

Since the highest correlations between kinematic variables and clinical scales were found in the Toyra® exercise of “Eating with spoon”, the Agility metric was computed only in this exercise. The results obtained by the patients were averaged for each level of injury, obtaining a value of 68.901 % (±25.184 %) for level C5; 77.523 % (±7.601 %) for level C6; 90.458 % ±0.064 % for level C7 and 42.426 % for level C8 (there was only one patient with this level of injury).

Discussion

The present study showed that some of the kinematic data recorded by VR system Toyra® correlated with functional scales specific for the UL function. While previous studies have showed correlations between kinematic measured in functional movement in controlled environments (Cacho et al. 2011; Tsao and Mirbagheri 2007; Chang et al. 2005), we wanted to take a step forward and analyzed basic ADL directly measuring not only analytical but also functional movements.

Functional scores showed negative low correlations with some kinematic variables in the basal assessment. Patients using Toyra® do not need a specific training to use the system. However, the first session that they perform is never recorded in order to patient understand how Toyra® works and check the correct system’s functioning. It is known that large doses of practice, on the order of hundreds of daily repetitions of UL movements, may be required to produce lasting neural changes and optimize motor learning (Lang et al. 2009). One reason some technologies are difficult to use in rehabilitation is because they require the user to spend effort learning and becoming familiarized with them (Lee et al. 2012). Based on this, we estimate that these results are coherent considering that the learning of a VR task is a process that requires time and experience, so the more subjects play the game, the more their skills and familiarity increase (Burke et al. 2009). For that reason, the performance of the VR task with Toyra® was not expected to be as good as the real at the beginning of the training. It would be interesting for future studies to figured out how much time and experience would be necessary to learn Toyra® VR tasks, to distinguish between improvements in the VR tasks and the performance in the real world.

Preliminary outcomes of our group (Dimbwadyo-Terrer et al. 2013; Trincado-Alonso et al. 2014) and other authors such as Cacho et al. (2011) have showed high correlations between UL analytical movements and clinical and functional scales. These results support the idea that kinematic measures like ROM and/or muscle strength are good predictive variables of functional abilities (Zariffa et al. 2012). The positive correlations found between kinematic and functional parameters in the post assessment (see Fig. 4) verifying that changes in UL functional performance detected by functional scales are also measured by the VR system Toyra®, concretely the related to shoulder movements. This results are coherent with the fact persons with a lesion of C5 and below usually have enough shoulder function to use it in a functional context (Rudhe and van Hedel 2009), so it is expected to find improvement in this joint some time after a rehabilitation period, where changes are expected mainly in the first 6 months after injury. These results were also in the line with previous works that studied the correlations between manual muscle tests and SCIM III self-care items where, the same as this study, it was found significant positive correlations \(({r}=0.47/{p}\le 0.50)\) between Grooming and Shoulder ABD (Rudhe and van Hedel 2009). Indeed, the authors affirmed that the SCIM III item “Grooming” appears to be especially well correlated with strength and capacity of hand and arm. However, it has been affirmed that the use of functional scales that directly observe the patient’s performance of relevant tasks in real time, might be more related to the movement kinematic assessments (Cacho et al. 2011), specially when measuring daily tasks. So, probably the results from these kind of scales would showed more and higher correlations with kinematic parameters. We also considered that, due to the sample of this study is mostly composed by people with SCI at the level of C5, changes in more joints might be expected in patients with better UL function.

The negative correlation between the SCIM III sub-item “Bathing upper body” and Toyra® activity “Drink Shoulder ABD/ADD” could be explained by the fact that “Bathing upper body” comprises activities (soaping, washing or drying body and head) where shoulder performs a wide variety of movements in different directions. However, Toyra® drink activity requires only reaching the glass and drinking, an activity where the shoulder ROM didn’t vary too much in the ABD/ADD movement. We think that, in that case, the difference between the real and VR task could affect the results. Moreover, the study published by Rudhe and van Hedel (2009) showed no significant correlations between Shoulder ABD and Bathing upper body SCIM III item; results that support the ones found in the present study.

Regarding the Agility metric, the results showed a positive trend for descending levels of injury C5, C6 and C7, namely the higher the level of injury, the lower the agility value. These results are in line with our expectations, since in complete tetraplegia higher levels of injury implicate lower UL function. Only the level C8 did not match this trend, probably because there was only one subject with this level of injury, which is insufficient to characterize this group.

To verify whether changes in UL functional performance detected by functional scales are also measured by the VR system, we assessed functional performance with SCIM III scale and the VR systems at the beginning and at the end of 4 week of conventional rehabilitation and a training with the VR system. Due to the patients were in the sub-acute phase, it was expected to find some functional changes after this period in basic daily tasks, since it was seen that basic activities, which involve more isolated movements of body parts, may be easier to train and perform at the beginning of the rehabilitation, especially for persons with a cervical complete SCI (Spooren et al. 2008). In previous studies of our group, we have proved the accuracy of Toyra® system, and the associated biomechanical model, as well as their suitability for clinical use, by analyzing complex UL real tasks and validating using a commercial optoelectronic system (Gil-Agudo et al. 2013; De los Reyes-Guzmán et al. 2010). These studies suggest that the inertial sensor-based motion tracking system used in this study, can be employ in patients who have UL impairment through data integration with the VR system Toyra®.

The results in this study showed significant changes in the total score of self-care category of SCIM III after 4 week of rehabilitation, as well as in all movements in 4 of the 5 Toyra® exercises. These findings supported the hypothesis that kinematic analysis complements clinical and functional assessments of patients with tetraplegia, mainly the characteristics of the motor strategies used during the performance of a motor ADL task (Cacho et al. 2011). Also we think that this study showed that it is possible to conduct a full objective kinematic assessment of the entire UL, while performing basic ADL activities using VR systems and real-time monitoring.

Regarding the SCIM III sub-items, we found significant changes in 2 of the 6 SCIM III sub-items. However, 4 of 5 Toyra® exercises presented significant changes. It could support the theory that even though SCIM III is the most sensitive scale to measure changes in function during the rehabilitation of people with SCI (Catz et al. 2001), the current functional and clinical scales are not enough sensible to measure small changes and can yield subjective bias (Cacho et al. 2011; De Los Reyes-Guzmán et al. 2013). Also, we have to take into account that there is a limitation in comparing real and VR tasks that can influence in this results. Furthermore, we were assessed ADL, and SCIM III test takes into account parameters as use of technical aids or necessity to external support to execute the task that difficult to take into account in a VR environment.

Conclusion

The correlations found between functional and kinematic parameters in this study might indicate that Toyra® system could be a good estimator of functionality, mainly in parameters related to shoulder movements. It would be necessary a study with a large sample and where more VR ADL tasks will be compared with scales that measure real-time functional tasks. The Agility metric obtain from the VR system showed that functional metrics might be suitable for clinical assessment, although more research need to be done using more metrics to different ADL tasks. The changes showed in both functional and kinematics variables after a period of rehabilitation and VR-based functional practice, offer objective functional data that could complement currently clinical assessments. As future work, this study allows us to open a new area of research based on the validation of different motor capture systems not only as kinematic but also functional tools, making it possible to measure ADL in an objective way. These results can inform the clinicians on the efficacy of the different rehabilitation methods and their impact on the patients’ functionality. Another future field of work is the development of telerehabilitation platforms, where doctors and therapists can continue to remote patient outcomes from data recorded during therapy sessions, obtaining real-time data and recreating real virtual environments to practice daily living skills.
